topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade 2.0: Changes and Additions from Version 1.1

body.p: HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade (HOSCG) is a product that satisfies stringent performance and uptime requirements from Telecom service providers. This is built upon:

ul.li: Helion OpenStack 2.0 (Keystone, Glance, Cinder, Neutron, Horizon, Heat, Ceilometer, HA Architecture, Logging, Monitoring, Installer),
Wind River Titanium (which includes Nova among other OpenStack services, Accelerated Virtual Switch and Wind River Linux underneath),
DCN (HP resells Nuage VSP) as SDN Controller with its own vswitch - Virtual Routing and Switching (VRS) supporting ESX and KVM hypervisors

body.p: Telefonica is the largest stake holder in driving features and requirements for HCG 2.0, and we have come up with two Stock Keeping Units (SKUs). They are primarily based on vSwitch choices - Wind River AVS or DCN VRS. DCN VRS SKU addresses most of Telefonica's requirements whereas AVS SKU is for customers who are focused on Virtualized Infrastructure Manager (VIM) key features like line rate performance and high availability and they are not much serious about automating networking end to end, multi-dc, multi-hypervisor etc. A brief description of these SKUs is as follows:

ul.li: HCG-AVS refers to the SKU that customers buy when they want AVS as their choice of vSwitch for their WR KVM compute nodes. This SKU supports only the WR KVM hypervisor.

HCG-VRS refers to the SKU that customers buy when they want VRS as their choice of vSwitch for their WR KVM compute nodes. This SKU supports both WR KVM and VMware ESXi hypervisors as well as limited support for baremetal as a service.

body.p: Telecom companies (such as Telefonica and Nokia) desiring cloud-based Network Function Virtualization (NFV).
HCG 2.0 Architecture is built upon HCG 1.1 with the following key differences:

ol.li: WR computes can support vSwitch of your choice - AVS or VRS: To enable this feature, we are replacing AVS with VRS based on the product SKU being selected. The architecture toggles between Neutron being a shared service (HCG-VRS) to dedicated service per region (HCG-AVS). The architecture for both products is documented on this one architecture page. Both products share many components. Many of the interfaces have not changed since HCG 1.1 other than being renumbered as part of cleaning up this page.

Baremetal Region to provide baremetal provisioning as a service: We extended the architecture by adding another control plane (single node) running identical services plus ironic but in different region - nova, neutron and ironic

VxLAN to VLAN bridging: We are now using HPN 5930/7900 switches in the architecture as enabler for providing VxLAN to VLAN switching. This is specifically for VMs with virtio vNICs to communicate with baremetal ports like SR-IOV, PCI-PT and Host Port.
Enhance Standard control plane for Backup, Logging and Monitoring services for Standard region services: Added and enhanced new services like Icinga, Elastic-Logstash-Kibana (ELK), Attis services.
Infoblox as IPAM plugin: Neutron has now a plugin to support IP reservation through Infoblox appliance. Architecturally, it is an enhancement to Neutron Service running in each region.

ul.li: Standard Controller (Controller running on hLinux): Standard IaaS control plane very similar to HOS. The main difference is that DCN/Nuage is used for networking rather than OVS to enable cloud-to-cloud communication. Icinga has also been upgraded to Icinga2 to enable more monitoring features. Many components of this region are shared with the WR Region.

ESX Compute: Standard IaaS compute node using DCN/Nuage components for networking. The product has evolved such that there will be no compute nodes based on hLinux KVM for 2.0. One offering will not have any ESX compute nodes and also no DCN nodes. Another offering will have vCenter based ESX compute nodes. This component has sub component DCN VRS (Virtualized Routing & Switching). It provide L2/L3 capabilities to enable VMs to communicate within the cloud and for remote cloud communication.

WR Compute: Realtime compute node with Wind River (WR) networking components. Wind River Linux with a modified, realtime KVM run on these nodes. A change for 2.0 is that one of the HCG products will ship with DCN VRS and the other will ship with AVS networking configured.

BM Controller: Ironic server and compute proxy along with dependent services such as DHCP and DNS run on this single node to control requests for bare metal compute nodes. The bare metal controller and compute nodes run in their own region of the cloud.
BM Node: Bare metal node to be allocated and used on demand similar to a VM. They are managed by the BM Controller.

5930 Switch: HP Networking hardware switch to provide VxLAN to VLAN Bridging for SR-IOV, PC-PT or Baremtal Host ports. It also provides DHCP services to these baremetal ports. We have plans to use this for external network connectivity to replace software gateway VRS-G.
Infoblox: 3rd party product requested by Telefonica to support IPAM. Infoblox will be optional for other customers and is not expected to be used.

HLM: Helion Lifecycle Manager deploys and manages the Standard Region consisting of the Standard Controller running shared services and the nodes required to run DCN. HLM will deploy and manage the WR region using a delegation model with some configuration rather than at the sub-component level as is done in the Standard Region.
DCN VSC (Virtualized Services Controller): DCN/Nuage component to route traffic between VMs and coordinate with VSD for remote cloud communication.
DCN VRS-G (Virtualized Routing & Switching Gateway): DCN/Nuage gateway to enable VMs to communicate outside the cloud and for remote cloud communication.
DCN VSD (Virtualized Services Directory): DCN/Nuage component to coordinate communication between clouds and manage L2 and L3 security policies.
StoreVirtual/3PAR: Hardware storage array used as backend for Cinder. Support for 3PAR has a similar architecture as StoreVirtual on iSCSI, not Fibre.

WR Controller: Realtime control plane for compute and networking. This is a substantial subset of the Wind River Titanium Server (TiS). Wind River has modified versions of most of the OpenStack components in this control plane.
Orchestrator: This could be any application consuming the cloud services. The NFV team has created NFV Director but some customers will use their own applications.

body.p: See also Architecture section at CG Helion Product Documentation
Summary of controls spanning multiple components and interfaces:

ul.li: Audit: OpenStack services, mySQL, RabbitMQ, HLM CP, Ansible, Cobbler perform logging. Logs are collected by the centralized logging service.

li.p: Authentication: Authentication via Keystone tokens at APIs. Password authentication to Nuage components and StoreVirtual.

ul.li: Authorization: OpenStack provides admin and non-admin roles that are indicated in session tokens. Processes run at minimum privilege. Processes run as unique user/group definitions. Appropriate filesystem controls prevent other processes from accessing service’s files. IPtables and ACLs at the network perimeter ensure that no unneeded ports are open.
Availability: Redundant hosts, clustered DB, clustered MQ, fail-over. Monitoring via centralized monitoring service.

li.p: Confidentiality: Network connections for outside access to APIs over TLS. Network separation via VLANs. Data and config files protected via filesystem controls. Separation of customer traffic on the TUL network via Open Flow (VxLANs).

ul.li: Integrity: Network connections for outside access to APIs over TLS. Network separation via VLANs. Data and config files are protected by filesystem controls.
